content: Have you heard of this dating service, AshleyMadison.com? What do you think of the service they offer? The CEO recently pointed out that countries that do not take such a "hard line" on monogamy actually have less divorce than here in the good US of A. From NPR: AshleyMadison.com, which caters to men and women who are already in relationships and are looking for something more, is the largest dating service of its kind. The Toronto-based company has made millions of dollars by helping people cheat on their spouses. Their tag line gets right to the point: "Life is short, have an affair." Their radio ads even recommend cheating on the company dime. "When you have a private moment at work today, visit AshleyMadison.com. You'll be happy you came," the ads say. Don, a 52-year-old IT specialist living in Southern California who, not surprisingly, preferred not to give his real last name, is one of the site's hundreds of users. "The ad sounded pretty interesting, so I thought I'd give it a shot and see if I got any action," he says. Don, or "Don Deshizzle" as he is known online, says he is looking for an "NSA" — no strings attached — relationship. So far, he says, he has paid about $100 to e-mail and instant message with other Ashley Madison members. "What you do is you buy credits — I think 100 credits at a time for $55 — and then each e-mail you initiate costs five credits. You burn through them pretty quickly," he says. Don says he likes the site because it gives him the opportunity to be upfront about his marital status. "Because, I guess, all the cards are on the table. It's not like if you go to a singles or a standard site, then you kind of have the stigma of being a cheater and that doesn't seem right," he says. He doesn't feel too ethically troubled by what he's doing, he says, though he hasn't met anyone in person yet. As for the people profiting from the Ashley Madison Web site, they say they have no moral qualms. "This is just a business to me. This is a market need, just like any other business that's successful. There's huge demand for it," says Chief Operating Officer Noel Biderman, who is married with children. Biderman says he is faithful to his wife, but he doesn't object to the fact that cheaters have helped his online business make more than $20 million since it started in 2002. "This is just a fact of life. Monogamy is not in our DNA," he says. In fact, Biderman goes so far as to claim that a little infidelity may do a person good — helping an insecure man or woman reclaim a sense of self-worth. "Women come to a service like Ashley Madison because they haven't been sent roses or flowers in God knows how long. Valentine's Day gets forgotten. That re-validation comes in a female user in our site within 30 or 40 minutes — as a number of guys are knocking at her door and professing their desire to be with her," he says. "http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=88137694"

content: Stuff like this makes me ill. I figure, if a person doesn't want to be monogamous, then he/she has no business getting married. If you want to sleep around, then stay single. Just don't cheat on your spouse! But remember... people have been committing adultery as long as people have been getting married, so this is nothing new. Many of our Founding Fathers had mistresses. Some slept with their slaves. So, this is nothing new. Now, it's just neatly pixelated, digitalized, and payable via credit card for your convenience.

content: quote: Originally posted by Whirled_Peas: Stuff like this makes me ill. I figure, if a person doesn't want to be monogamous, then he/she has no business getting married. If you want to sleep around, then stay single. Just don't cheat on your spouse! But remember... people have been committing adultery as long as people have been getting married, so this is nothing new. Many of our Founding Fathers had mistresses. Some slept with their slaves. So, this is nothing new. Now, it's just neatly pixelated, digitalized, and payable via credit card for your convenience. I thought that way when I was 25.. But I've seen too many stories that have changed my mind. I had a friend, married for 10 years with 2 children, over beers one night tell me: My wife came home one night last week and told me she has no desire to have sex..ever. Now he stayed with her for a decade, did everything he could for her, took her to MD's and shrinks, and everything else you can think of...there was nothing wrong with her..she had just lost any desire to have sex. Now what is my friend going to do? He does not want to leave her, and have to be a part time dad to his boys..so he lives the res tof his life without sex? Really? I have another friend who's wife has been through dozens of medical procedures. He's stuck with her for years a she goes from treatment to treatment. He's given up most of his career for her. He's beomce mom and dad to his children. Would you begrudge him a night happiness? I think this works both ways, yes, its wrong to cheat..but yes it is also wrong to create a situation in which you expect your spouse to live without that physical love.

content: Have you heard of this dating service, AshleyMadison.com? What do you think of the service they offer? The CEO recently pointed out that countries that do not take such a "hard line" on monogamy actually have less divorce than here in the good US of A. From NPR: AshleyMadison.com, which caters to men and women who are already in relationships and are looking for something more, is the largest dating service of its kind. The Toronto-based company has made millions of dollars by helping people cheat on their spouses. Their tag line gets right to the point: "Life is short, have an affair." Their radio ads even recommend cheating on the company dime. "When you have a private moment at work today, visit AshleyMadison.com. You'll be happy you came," the ads say. Don, a 52-year-old IT specialist living in Southern California who, not surprisingly, preferred not to give his real last name, is one of the site's hundreds of users. "The ad sounded pretty interesting, so I thought I'd give it a shot and see if I got any action," he says. Don, or "Don Deshizzle" as he is known online, says he is looking for an "NSA" — no strings attached — relationship. So far, he says, he has paid about $100 to e-mail and instant message with other Ashley Madison members. "What you do is you buy credits — I think 100 credits at a time for $55 — and then each e-mail you initiate costs five credits. You burn through them pretty quickly," he says. Don says he likes the site because it gives him the opportunity to be upfront about his marital status. "Because, I guess, all the cards are on the table. It's not like if you go to a singles or a standard site, then you kind of have the stigma of being a cheater and that doesn't seem right," he says. He doesn't feel too ethically troubled by what he's doing, he says, though he hasn't met anyone in person yet. As for the people profiting from the Ashley Madison Web site, they say they have no moral qualms. "This is just a business to me. This is a market need, just like any other business that's successful. There's huge demand for it," says Chief Operating Officer Noel Biderman, who is married with children. Biderman says he is faithful to his wife, but he doesn't object to the fact that cheaters have helped his online business make more than $20 million since it started in 2002. "This is just a fact of life. Monogamy is not in our DNA," he says. In fact, Biderman goes so far as to claim that a little infidelity may do a person good — helping an insecure man or woman reclaim a sense of self-worth. "Women come to a service like Ashley Madison because they haven't been sent roses or flowers in God knows how long. Valentine's Day gets forgotten. That re-validation comes in a female user in our site within 30 or 40 minutes — as a number of guys are knocking at her door and professing their desire to be with her," he says. "http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=88137694"

reply: I thought that way when I was 25.. But I've seen too many stories that have changed my mind. I had a friend, married for 10 years with 2 children, over beers one night tell me: My wife came home one night last week and told me she has no desire to have sex..ever. Now he stayed with her for a decade, did everything he could for her, took her to MD's and shrinks, and everything else you can think of...there was nothing wrong with her..she had just lost any desire to have sex. Now what is my friend going to do? He does not want to leave her, and have to be a part time dad to his boys..so he lives the res tof his life without sex? Really? I have another friend who's wife has been through dozens of medical procedures. He's stuck with her for years a she goes from treatment to treatment. He's given up most of his career for her. He's beomce mom and dad to his children. Would you begrudge him a night happiness? content: Have you heard of this dating service, AshleyMadison.com? What do you think of the service they offer? The CEO recently pointed out that countries that do not take such a "hard line" on monogamy actually have less divorce than here in the good US of A. From NPR: AshleyMadison.com, which caters to men and women who are already in relationships and are looking for something more, is the largest dating service of its kind. The Toronto-based company has made millions of dollars by helping people cheat on their spouses. Their tag line gets right to the point: "Life is short, have an affair." Their radio ads even recommend cheating on the company dime. "When you have a private moment at work today, visit AshleyMadison.com. You'll be happy you came," the ads say. Don, a 52-year-old IT specialist living in Southern California who, not surprisingly, preferred not to give his real last name, is one of the site's hundreds of users. "The ad sounded pretty interesting, so I thought I'd give it a shot and see if I got any action," he says. Don, or "Don Deshizzle" as he is known online, says he is looking for an "NSA" — no strings attached — relationship. So far, he says, he has paid about $100 to e-mail and instant message with other Ashley Madison members. "What you do is you buy credits — I think 100 credits at a time for $55 — and then each e-mail you initiate costs five credits. You burn through them pretty quickly," he says. Don says he likes the site because it gives him the opportunity to be upfront about his marital status. "Because, I guess, all the cards are on the table. It's not like if you go to a singles or a standard site, then you kind of have the stigma of being a cheater and that doesn't seem right," he says. He doesn't feel too ethically troubled by what he's doing, he says, though he hasn't met anyone in person yet. As for the people profiting from the Ashley Madison Web site, they say they have no moral qualms. "This is just a business to me. This is a market need, just like any other business that's successful. There's huge demand for it," says Chief Operating Officer Noel Biderman, who is married with children. Biderman says he is faithful to his wife, but he doesn't object to the fact that cheaters have helped his online business make more than $20 million since it started in 2002. "This is just a fact of life. Monogamy is not in our DNA," he says. In fact, Biderman goes so far as to claim that a little infidelity may do a person good — helping an insecure man or woman reclaim a sense of self-worth. "Women come to a service like Ashley Madison because they haven't been sent roses or flowers in God knows how long. Valentine's Day gets forgotten. That re-validation comes in a female user in our site within 30 or 40 minutes — as a number of guys are knocking at her door and professing their desire to be with her," he says. "http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=88137694"

content: Stuff like this makes me ill. I figure, if a person doesn't want to be monogamous, then he/she has no business getting married. If you want to sleep around, then stay single. Just don't cheat on your spouse! But remember... people have been committing adultery as long as people have been getting married, so this is nothing new. Many of our Founding Fathers had mistresses. Some slept with their slaves. So, this is nothing new. Now, it's just neatly pixelated, digitalized, and payable via credit card for your convenience.
